awd_titl_txt: CRII: SHF: WINGS -- Wireless Interconnects for Next-Generation Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of low-latency, energy-efficient, and reconfigurable on-chip wireless interconnect infrastructure has the potential for reducing the carbon footprint of electronic systems. This research will be integrated with the graduate-level courses on design of VLSI and Nano-electronic devices to be taught by the PI at her institution. The dissemination of open-source software generated in this research via nano-HUB facilities at Purdue University is expected to provide significant impact by serving a broad community of students, researchers, and engineers. Further, the software generated in this research will be used for in-class projects and assignments providing students with a unique opportunity to learn about Exascale computing without abstracting the fundamentals of device physics. Undergraduate students will be advised through the undergraduate summer research program at NYU School of Engineering. Participation of the PI in National Center for Women in Technology program at NYU will facilitate involvement of underrepresented minorities in the research program. 

The technical objective of this research is to make major advances in the design and optimization of on-chip communications infrastructure by exploiting plasma waves in graphene to implement waveguides and nanoantennas. By marrying disparate technologies - CMOS electronics and graphene plasmonics - a new heterogeneous architecture is proposed to enable terahertz-band communication between several computing elements within a range of 10 cm.  The project will develop an analytical model-based benchmarked design space exploration of the interconnect architecture covering implementation aspects (area and energy) and network-level consideration (number of cores and network architecture). Overall, this research will drive connectivity to the full potential of scaled CMOS by improving communication bottleneck in a heterogeneous computing environment.

por.por_cntn:
The research was focused on gaining fundamental insight into the plasmonic properties of graphene nanostructures that could operate either as waveguides or optical nanoantennas for terahertz (THz) band communication. The THz band offers extremely high bandwidth, which could alleviate the spectrum scarcity and capacity limits of current wireless technologies, which are limited to bandwidths of less than 10 GHz. The ability of graphene to support plasma waves over a broad frequency spectrum is attractive for building a wide variety of electro-optic components such as waveguides, reflectarrays, antennas, photodetectors, phase shifters, and also as biological sensors. In addition, the propagating plasma waves in graphene have a high propagation velocity and long lifetimes. Therefore, graphene serves as an ideal platform to build plasmonic waveguides for on-chip communication and ultra-broadband antennas for wireless communication.

In this research, we developed a theoretical (semi-classical) framework to compute the dynamical conductivity of single-layer, few-layer, and bilayer graphene. This computational framework was then provided as an input to numerical finite-difference time-domain simulations to design, optimize, and  benchmark graphene plasmonic components. Below we briefly highlight some key results in various graphene-based high-frequency devices.   

Gate-voltage tunability and impact of interface states on plasmons in single-layer graphene: We quantified the role of gate voltage and thickness of gate dielectric on the characteristics of plasmon propagation in graphene by accounting for both the interface trap capacitance (substrate dangling bongs and gate-insulator traps) and the quantum capacitance. The gate volt- age serves as a powerful knob to tweak the carrier concentration and allows building electrically reconfigurable terahertz devices. By optimizing the gate voltage to maximize the plasmon propagation length in gated graphene structures, we derived simple scaling trends that provided intuitive insight into device modeling and design.

Bilayer graphene waveguides: Our theoretical calculations showed that in the case of bilayer graphene the energy asymmetry could be harnessed to increase the propagation length of transverse magnetic plasmons. Furthermore, when used as a channel in a dual-gate structure, the independent modulation of the asymmetry and the Fermi level in bilayer graphene could provide flexibility in configuring plasmonic characteristics post device fabrication.

Optical nonlinearity in graphene: We theoretically modeled the dispersion characteristics of surface plasmons in a graphene-based parallel-plate waveguide geometry using nonlinear Kerr-type core (inter-plate) dielectric. The optical nonlinearity of graphene in the terahertz band under high light intensity was specifically included in the analysis. Our results showed that optical nonlinearity led to the emergency of new propagating plasmon modes in the waveguide geometry. Uniquely, these new modes have extremely high localization length with one of the modes possessing negative group velocity. By changing the light intensity and electrochemical potential in graphene, we showed the potential of reconfiguring the properties of the waveguide based on system and application specific requirements.  

Pulse distortion in few-layer graphene waveguides: We analytically modeled the propagation speed and pulse-width distortion of a narrow-band Gaussian signal at THz frequency propagating through graphene. The consequences of signal distortion and attenuation on limiting the signal bit-rate and the impact on energy dissipation were quantified. A partition length of the plasmonic waveguide that distinguishes between the LC- and RC-dominated regimes of signal transport was derived. Upon comparison with on-chip electrical interconnects, we identified the energy budget that could be allocated toward plasmonic transceivers, such that the overall plasmonic communication was more energy efficient compared to electrical communication.

Graphene plasmonic nanoantennas: Nanonntennas are critical elements of nanoscale wireless communication technologies with potential to overcome some of the limitations of on-chip interconnects. We focused on modeling the resonant features of graphene-based nanoantennas (GNAs) that are characterized by their high Purcell factors, strong scattering mechanisms and sub-wavelength localization of light. Specifically we focused on three dimer geometries: bowtie, rectangular, and circular. We also developed an equivalent circuit model using RF circuit theory, antenna theory, and FDTD simulations and characterized the GNA figures of merit with respect to the physical properties of graphene and the substrate used. The circuit models could be readily used in a hierarchical circuit simulator to design and optimize optical nanoantennas for THz communication in high-performance computing systems.
